attributes.name: Class Grafts and NPC stat blocks

handouts.blobNotes:
CN resort town
Population 150,000 (17% human [mostly hylki], 12% ysoki, 4% space goblin, 4% ikeshti, 3% shobhad, 60% other)
Government plutocracy
Qualities notorious
Maximum Item Level 8th

Qualities

Khefak Depot lies at the center of sprawling fields of wrecked starships. The town was originally built as a ranch and holding center for khefaks turned loose on the Outer Junkfields to feed, giving the settlement its name. Over time, ranchers realized they could make serious money catering to visitors eager to wander the ruins searching for old junk. Now known more colloquially as Junker’s Delight, the town capitalizes on its proximity to acres of crashed starships, extracting every possible credit from tourists who hope to salvage some long-lost bit of forgotten technology—and strike it rich. Most of the depot’s inhabitants are transient, about a third are permanent residents, and most of those work in the hospitality and tourism industry.

In Khefak Depot, everything revolves around tourism, from the hotels and restaurants to guided tours and junk-hunting expeditions, with options at every price point for the discerning and the gullible alike. Respected universities and historical societies maintain small remote branches here, staffed by scholars and graduate students looking to make a name for themselves. Like the rest of Akiton, the town tends to be anarchic. Half a dozen individuals—the heads of families who own property and the largest businesses in town—form an unofficial council that serves as the only real authority. Among these individuals, the Water Dealer holds the most power, but he can’t ignore his lesser rivals. There’s no official law enforcement agency, but all the big families and many smaller businesses maintain private security forces to protect their clientele.

Most of the higher-end businesses and resorts ring the edge of town, called “the Skirt” by locals. The rest of the streets run in concentric rings connected along spokes at close to cardinal and ordinal directions. The original plans for the city had the spokes running straight along the compass rose, but the realities of building and an inebriated surveyor made that just a dream. Since the town’s founding, streets have also shifted to accommodate construction projects and mergers. The buildings around the Skirt tend to be the tallest, although a few upstart entrepreneurs have tried to build taller edifices off the Skirt with varying degrees of success. Residential housing takes up most of the town’s interior, along with recreational facilities such as the arena and racetracks.

Why are We Here?

When starting a new campaign with new characters, consider how the player characters know one another and why they travel together. If your group makes characters together (especially if there’s a session devoted to this activity), your players might collaborate to craft the relationships between their characters. To help with this, select one of the three backgrounds presented below, detailing why the player characters journey to Khefak Depot. You can do this before characters are even made, using the decision to guide character creation, or you can wait to see the party’s composition and then pick the plot hook that best fits your group. Make sure everyone is happy with this decision, as it affects the tone of certain encounters in the adventure.

Although the heroes will engage with other stories in and around Khefak Depot that drive the story forward, their initial reason for coming to town will continue to be relevant and might influence their decisions. The chosen background might also inform what the characters do after the events of Junker’s Delight, should the group continue adventuring.

Discount Treasure Seekers

The heroes are friends looking to uncover anything that’ll make them rich and famous. Perhaps they seek artifacts or treasures that will secure them entry to the Starfinder Society (or some other prestigious organization) or get them an audience with Zo!, a celebrity entertainer and media mogul from Eox. They might revel in the thrill of discovery, or seek riches and an early retirement. Each member of the group can have their own motive as long as they all share the same broad goal.

Unfortunately, the player characters don’t have the funds for an expedition into the uncharted galaxies of deep space. One of them recently learned about the junk tourism going on at Khefak Depot, and that visitors sometimes stumble across antique technology that’s worth a fortune. The odds of the heroes scoring the same good luck are poor, but no reward comes without risk. The group has scraped together enough credits for one-way tickets to Khefak Depot on Akiton, via the trench city of Maro; however, the players don’t need to worry about the cost of this journey coming out of their starting cash. Once in Khefak Depot, it will be up to the player characters to search for any clues that might lead them to some kind of lost treasure.

Friend of the Family

Sully (CG male shirren) is an elderly veteran of the war against the Swarm. He mustered out of the army a decade ago and has spent the intervening years on Castrovel as a used enercycle salesman. But his joints are starting to hurt, and he’s moved to Akiton, where he hopes the drier weather will be better for his health. One or more of the player characters are old friends or relatives of Sully; these characters don’t need to be shirren, and you can change Sully’s species if you wish. One hero might have served alongside Sully in the war, while another shares Sully’s interest in vintage enercycles or Castrovellian cuisine. In any case, the characters have developed a close bond with Sully over the years.

Sully’s not as young as he used to be, and Khefak Depot is a dangerous place; he needs help in his new endeavor. Thus, he’s paid for his friends to travel to Maro, where a driver will take them the rest of the way to Khefak Depot. Alternatively, make up a character of your own to use instead of Sully, tailoring the NPC to the characters your players have created.

Looking for Steady Work

Living in the Pact Worlds isn’t free, and the heroes need employment. The Khefak Depot city council recently put out a public service message across infospheres in the system that their little settlement is constantly growing and offers steady jobs to those with “strong backs, clever minds, and the will to work.” The advertisement doesn’t offer much in the way of specifics, but the player characters don’t have any other opportunities on their plates. Their reasons for wanting to work can be varied—perhaps one needs to pay off a debt, another sends credits home to support their family, while a third is just looking forward to some shiny new equipment. Whatever the case, they’re heading to Akiton!

How do they know one another? With their common interest of finding work, the heroes have been matched by an infosphere site that helps those in need of employment pool their money for interplanetary transport to places looking for workers. The player characters meet in person for the first time on the one-way flight to Akiton, where they have a few days to get to know each other. They’re scheduled to land in the trench city of Maro and can find transport to Khefak Depot waiting for them there. This journey has already been paid for, so the players don’t need to worry about it coming out of their starting credits. Once in Khefak Depot, the characters will need to search for potential jobs.

Junk Gear

To some, rusted metal and broken electronics are mere trash, but to others, they’re raw materials for crafting interesting—and unorthodox—equipment. Some of the items below appear in the adventure, created by those living in Khefak Depot or the Outer Junkfields, where garbage is literally everywhere.

  • Breakaway Aegis
  • Disposal Blade, Tactical
  • Disposal Blade, Advanced
  • Disposal Blade, Ultrathin
  • Disposal Blade, Zero-Edge
  • Junk Camouflage
  • Junk Drone
  • Rubbish Cannon, Light
  • Rubbish Cannon, Standard
  • Rubbish Cannon, Heavy
  • Salvage Chassis
  • Scrap Spikes, Tactical
  • Scrap Spikes, Advanced
  • Scrap Spikes, Ultrathin
  • Scrap Spikes, Zero-Edge

Junk Spells

Some spellcasters find magical uses for objects others consider trash. Additional junk-related spells can be found in Starfinder Pact Worlds and Starfinder Near Space, where some of the spells described below first appeared.

  • Fabricate Scrap
  • Junk Armor
  • Junk Barricade
  • Junk Restraints
  • Junk Shanty

Junkomancer (Archetype)

Taking an Archetype

The rules for archetypes can be found in the Core Rulebook. To take an archetype, you must choose it when you gain a level matching the earliest level for which that archetype grants an alternate class feature (for example, a character wishing to take the junkomancer archetype must take Scrap Expert at 2nd level). Once you’ve made that decision, you are “locked in” to that archetype and must, unless otherwise noted, take its alternate class features at the presented levels. Which class features you swap for an archetype’s abilities depend on your class. Be sure to consider what you might be giving up before you commit to an archetype!

Monsters

  • Drift Phantom
  • Junk Golem
  • Thastertoad

Technomancer 0
School universal; see text
Casting Time 1 standard action
Range close
Effect creates or converts 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment
Duration instantaneous
Saving Throw Will negates (object); Spell Resistance yes (object); see text

You turn 1 bulk of inert matter, such as debris, dust, rocks, or other unattended 0-level items, into 1 bulk of junked electronic equipment suitable for targeting with spells such as battle junkbot, handy junkbot, healing junkbot, junk armor, junk restraints, or junksword. The junked electronics have no resale value and can’t be repaired into any functioning item. Any direct examination by a character trained in Engineering or Physical Science reveals the useless nature of the junk.

What is Junk?

Many of the spells here refer to "1 bulk of inert electronic equipment." Valid targets include a large broken computer system, nonworking or unconnected computer or robot parts, a destroyed robot or similar trashed mechanical system, or any related electronic components or combination of the above, so long as the junk adds up to a sufficient quantity.

Technomancer 1
School conjuration (creation)
Casting Time 1 standard action
Range touch
Target at least 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment; see text
Duration 24 hours (D)
Saving Throw none; Spell Resistance no

You turn a pile of technological junk into a suit of light armor, or use it to upgrade a suit of light armor into heavy armor. You must target inert, nonworking electronic equipment of at least 1 bulk.

You can cause the armor to be created on yourself or an adjacent willing or unconscious ally. Light or heavy armor you create requires proficiency to use without penalties as normal. If you use this spell to create light armor, the armor has an EAC bonus equal to your caster level, a KAC bonus equal to your caster level + 2, and a maximum Dex bonus equal to 1 + one quarter your caster level. Using junk armor to temporarily turn light armor into heavy armor increases the armor’s EAC bonus by 1 and its KAC bonus by 2, reduces its maximum Dexterity bonus by 3, and worsens its armor check penalty by 2.

What is Junk?

Many of the spells here refer to "1 bulk of inert electronic equipment." Valid targets include a large broken computer system, nonworking or unconnected computer or robot parts, a destroyed robot or similar trashed mechanical system, or any related electronic components or combination of the above, so long as the junk adds up to a sufficient quantity.

Technomancer 4
School conjuration (creation)
Casting Time 1 standard action
Range touch
Target at least 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment; see text
Duration 1 round/level (D)
Saving Throw none; Spell Resistance no

You turn a pile of technological junk into a barricade that provides cover. You must target inert, nonworking electronic equipment of at least 1 bulk.

The junk you target stacks and reinforces itself to form a low wall along one edge of your square. The barricade grants cover against attacks with a line of effect that pass through it. The barricade has hardness and Hit Points as a piece of equipment with an item level equal to your caster level.

You can target 1 additional bulk of inert electronic equipment for every 4 caster levels you have beyond 4th, extending the barricade across an equal number of adjacent squares. Alternatively, for each additional bulk you can target, you can increase the bonuses to AC and Reflex saves provided by one square of the barricade by 1 (to a maximum of improved cover—+8 bonus to AC and +4 bonus to Reflex saves).

What is Junk?

Many of the spells here refer to "1 bulk of inert electronic equipment." Valid targets include a large broken computer system, nonworking or unconnected computer or robot parts, a destroyed robot or similar trashed mechanical system, or any related electronic components or combination of the above, so long as the junk adds up to a sufficient quantity.

Technomancer 4
School transmutation
Casting Time 1 standard action
Range close (25 ft. + 5 ft./2 levels)
Targets at least 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment; see text
Duration 1 round/2 levels (D)
Saving Throw Reflex negates; see text; Spell Resistance no

You turn a pile of technological junk into fetters and shackles that restrain a creature within range. You must target inert, nonworking electronic equipment of at least 1 bulk.

While casting this spell, you use your magic and technological know-how to rearrange the junked parts and infuse them with energy powerful enough to restrain a Large or smaller creature. The junk flies towards the creature and ensnares it, usually by attaching to the creature’s limbs. If the targeted creature succeeds at a Reflex save, the junk lands adjacent to them without harm. Otherwise, the ensnared target gains the entangled condition for the duration of the spell, or until it ends the condition by taking a move action and succeeding at an Acrobatics or Athletics check with a DC equal to 15 + 1-1/2 × your caster level.

What is Junk?

Many of the spells here refer to "1 bulk of inert electronic equipment." Valid targets include a large broken computer system, nonworking or unconnected computer or robot parts, a destroyed robot or similar trashed mechanical system, or any related electronic components or combination of the above, so long as the junk adds up to a sufficient quantity.

Technomancer 5
School conjuration (creation)
Casting Time 1 standard action
Range touch
Targets at least 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment
Duration 1 hour/level (D)
Saving Throw none; Spell Resistance no

You turn a pile of technological junk into an extradimensional shelter. You must target inert, nonworking electronic equipment of at least 1 bulk.

The junk you target forms into a doorway 4 feet wide and 8 feet high, which becomes the entrance to an extra-dimensional dwelling that can comfortably fit up to 8 Medium creatures. A Large creature counts as two Medium creatures, and a Huge creature counts as four Medium creatures. Only those you designate can enter the shanty. When you enter it, the portal shuts and the doorway reverts to a pile of junk. You can reform the doorway and the portal again from your side at will.

The shanty is one large room with furnishings made of scrap and debris. Despite its shabby appearance, it’s surprisingly comfortable. Characters who take a full night’s rest within the shanty benefit as if they underwent complete bed rest for 24 hours, recovering Hit Points and ability damage at double the usual rate. The atmosphere and temperature inside the shelter are enjoyable for your species. Since it can be entered only through its special portal, outside conditions do not affect the shanty, nor do conditions inside it pass beyond.

What is Junk?

Many of the spells here refer to "1 bulk of inert electronic equipment." Valid targets include a large broken computer system, nonworking or unconnected computer or robot parts, a destroyed robot or similar trashed mechanical system, or any related electronic components or combination of the above, so long as the junk adds up to a sufficient quantity.

Some spellcasters work their magic through high-tech computers or objects of mystical significance, but you have found a kind of arcane power in the mundane. Scrap metal and inert electronics are your paints, and reality is your canvas.

The secrets of junk magic are especially common on Akiton, where junkomancers defend struggling settlements and nomadic wanderers alike.

Taking an Archetype

The rules for archetypes can be found in the Core Rulebook. To take an archetype, you must choose it when you gain a level matching the earliest level for which that archetype grants an alternate class feature (for example, a character wishing to take the junkomancer archetype must take Scrap Expert at 2nd level). Once you’ve made that decision, you are “locked in” to that archetype and must, unless otherwise noted, take its alternate class features at the presented levels. Which class features you swap for an archetype’s abilities depend on your class. Be sure to consider what you might be giving up before you commit to an archetype!

Prerequisite

Only characters who have the spells class feature (such as mystics and technomancers) can take this archetype.

Alternate Class Features

The archetype grants alternate class features at 2nd, 4th, and 18th levels.

Scrap Expert (Sp) [2nd Level] As a spell-like ability, you can cast fabricate scrap as a swift action a number of times per day equal to your key ability score modifier.

Junk Spell Master (Su) [4th level] You know an additional 1st-level spell and you gain an additional 1st-level spell slot. At 7th level, you know an additional 2nd-level spell and you gain an additional 2nd-level spell slot. At 10th level, you know an additional 3rd-level spell and you gain an additional 3rd-level spell slot. At 13th level, you know an additional 4th-level spell and you gain an additional 4th-level spell slot. At 16th level, you know an additional 5th-level spell and you gain an additional 5th-level spell slot. At 19th level, you know an additional 6th-level spell and you gain an additional 6th-level spell. For each of these extra spells known, they must be one whose Targets entry lists “at least 1 bulk of electronic material,” and you can use these extra spell slots only to cast spells with this target.

Junk Form (Su) [18th Level] You can, as a swift action, transform parts of your body into pieces of junk and metal debris. In this state, you gain immunity to bleed, disease, nonlethal damage, paralysis, poison, and stunning. You gain a +4 enhancement bonus to Fortitude saving throws, unless the effect prompting the saving throw works on objects or is harmless. You can end junk form with a swift action. You can remain in this form for a number of minutes per day equal to twice your key ability score modifier. You don’t need to use this duration all at once, but you must use it in 1-minute increments

attributes.name: Thank You For Purchasing Junker's Delight!
Appendix 1 - Creating Monsters And Other NPCs
Player Art Handout: Drift Power Core
Player Art Handout: Tracing the Signal
Player Art Handout: Concluding the Adventure

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: Gear salvage chassis, mega-junklaser with 2 batteries (20 charges each)

attribs.name: organization
attribs.current: tribe (1 plus 13+ zaperators, 13+ noncombatants, and 5-6 alien pets)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezaUkvHnUrqHxQPRpw_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, Bomguzzle can let out a screech that puts all non-goblinoid creatures within 30 feet on edge. Each affected creature must succeed at a DC 14 Will saving throw or gain the off-target condition for 1d4 rounds. Whether successful or not, a creature can’t be affected by Bomguzzle’s disturbing screech again for 24 hours. This is a mind-affecting, sense-dependent effect.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezaUkvHnUrqHxQPRpx_description
attribs.current: As a move action, Bomguzzle can remove the penalties associated with the broken condition from a single piece of equipment until the start of his next turn. The item then becomes unusable for 10 minutes (and retains the broken condition after that until it’s fixed).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezaUkvHnUrqHxQPRpy_description
attribs.current: The laser rifle mounted on Bomguzzle’s powered armor is crafted from a mishmash of broken casings, leaking energy cells, and other random material. A mega-junklaser is similar to an azimuth laser rifle, except it has a range of only 80 feet. If Bomguzzle rolls a natural 1 when attacking with it, he must immediately attempt a DC 20 Engineering check. Success means that the mega-junklaser gains the broken condition. Failure means that the weapon explodes in 1d3–1 rounds, functioning as an incendiary grenade I (explode [5 ft., 1d6 F, 1d4 burn, DC 14]); a result of 0 rounds means the mega-junklaser explodes immediately—randomly determine the corner of the wielder’s square that’s the center of the burst. Bomguzzle can dismount the mega-junklaser as a full action, and he can throw it like a grenade, but it has only a 10-foot range increment.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezaUkvHnUrqHxQPRpw_effect
attribs.current: gain the off-target condition for [[1d4]] rounds

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: graphite carbon skin, azimuth laser pistol with 2 batteries (20 charges each), mk 1 serums of healing (2)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-0qLEKUTnjDkMZqEg_description
attribs.current: Tezz Tronnin is aligned to the cycles of solar systems. Unlike a player-character solarian, Tezz is always considered attuned while using stellar revelations. However, she isn’t always considered fully attuned, so she can’t always use her zenith revelations. When you roll initiative for Tezz, roll 1d3. Once that many rounds have elapsed, Tezz is considered fully attuned and gains access to black hole supernova. After she uses one of these abilities, she’s no longer fully attuned; roll 1d3 again to see how many rounds she will take to recharge.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-0xCHXmpACGHySWRZ_description
attribs.current: As a solarian, Tezz gains a physical manifestation of her stellar power. The base form of her solar manifestation, when not actively in use, is a mote of stellar energy slightly smaller than a fist that hovers near her head. It glows an angry red color and sheds dim light in a 20-foot radius. Tezz can shut off the glow as a standard action to blend in or assist in stealth, but whenever she enters combat, the light returns immediately. Only Tezz can interact with her solar manifestation. No other creature or effect can affect her solar manifestation in any way, including disarming or sundering it. Tezz can seize her mote in one hand to form a melee weapon from stellar energy. It deals slashing damage. Forming or dismissing this solar weapon is a move action that takes the same amount of effort as drawing or sheathing a weapon (and can be combined with moving up to her speed as a single move action). Tezz’s solar weapon is automatically dismissed if it ever leaves her hand.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-1lia47JlKqg-BSKm_description
attribs.current: When Tezz is fully attuned, as a standard action, she can pull any number of creatures within 20 feet of her closer. She chooses which creatures are affected and which ones aren’t. Each target must succeed at a DC 14 Fortitude save or be pulled 10 feet toward her. Solid objects don’t block this ability, but any creature that runs into a solid object ceases moving closer. Creatures moved by this ability don’t provoke attacks of opportunity from the movement. Black hole functions as a zenith revelation for the purposes of abilities that reference it.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-1w2MbcEmpTohXCXR_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, Tezz can wreathe herself in stellar fire and make a charge without the usual penalties for charging. She can substitute a bull rush combat maneuver for the melee attack at the end of the charge. If she attempts this bull rush, the target takes 2d6 fire damage (DC 14 Reflex save for half), regardless of whether she succeeds.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-2LUl3SkmiQ39Wxw6_description
attribs.current: When Tezz is fully attuned, as a standard action, she can deal 4d6 fire damage to all creatures within 10 feet of her. A creature that succeeds at a DC 14 Reflex save takes half damage. Supernova functions as a zenith revelation for the purposes of abilities that reference them.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-2LUl3SkmiQ39Wxw6_effect
attribs.current: [[4d6]] fire damage to all creatures within 10 feet of her

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: squad defiance series, ember flame doshko with 2 batteries (20 charges each), tactical crossbolter with 20 arrows

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-6rXMDTL2rp2weleH_description
attribs.current: Do’trulu has four arms and can wield and hold up to four hands’ worth of weapons and equipment. While this increases the number of items he can have at the ready, it doesn’t increase the number of attacks he can make in combat.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-6vJ374sWmf6UU2pT_description
attribs.current: When Do’trulu is reduced to 0 Hit Points, he continues fighting for 1 more round. He can act normally until the end of his next turn; if he has 0 Hit Points at the end of that turn, he dies. If he would lose further Hit Points before this, he dies.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-72cleABlCFKAYuoy_description
attribs.current: As a soldier, Do’trulu has the blitz fighting style, which increases his speed and responsiveness to get into the thick of melee combat.

attribs.name: immunities
attribs.current: bleed, critical hits, paralysis, poison, sleep effects, stunning

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-7tBtccYY2NZGQlLk_description
attribs.current: The target becomes paralyzed and freezes in place. It is aware and breathes normally but can't take any physical actions even speech. A held creature can't cast spells. Each round on its turn the target can spend a full action to attempt a new saving throw to end the effect. This does not provoke attacks of opportunity. A winged creature that is paralyzed can't flap its wings and falls. A swimmer can't swim and may drown.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-846n-wL9MHPpXWEM_description
attribs.current: You telepathically rack the target's mind and body with agonizing pain that imposes a -2 penalty to ability checks attack rolls and skill checks. A target that succeeds at a Will saving throw reduces the duration to 1 round.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8DLvezMg2Kz5MN2P_description
attribs.current: This spell causes a single creature to become confused for 1 round. Any confused creature that is attacked automatically attacks or attempts to attack its attackers on its next turn as long as it is still confused at the start of its next turn. Note that a confused creature will not make attacks of opportunity against any foe that it is not already devoted to attacking (either because of its most recent action or because it has just been attacked). For confused creatures that have not been attacked roll on the following table at the start of each affected creature's turn each round to see what it does in that round. [D% - BEHAVIOR] 1-25 Act normally; 26-50 Do nothing but babble incoherently; 51-75 Deal 1d8 + Str modifier damage to self with item in hand; 76-100 Attack nearest creature. A confused creature that can't carry out the indicated action does nothing but babble incoherently. Attackers are not at any special advantage when attacking a confused target.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8byD5sDAP62OF5ko_duration
attribs.current: [[floor(@{caster_level}*10)]] minutes or until dismissed (D); see text

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8byD5sDAP62OF5ko_description
attribs.current: You create a shimmering skin-like coating of mystical force that covers your body allowing you to reflect damage you take back against your attacker. At any time during this spell's duration when you take Hit Point damage from an attack made with a weapon by a foe within 100 feet you can choose to dismiss the spell as a reaction. If you do the armor crackles with energy as it disappears arcing through the air to strike the attacking creature which takes an amount of force damage equal to the damage dealt to you at the time this spell was dismissed (maximum 10). The target can attempt a Reflex save for half damage.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8dRZlvJhOuKT5p7Q_description
attribs.current: You draw forth otherworldly energy to create a small spherical floating wisp that can distract your enemies in combat. This wisp can move 60 feet per round in any direction and you can direct it as a move action on your turn. If the wisp occupies the same space as an enemy the wisp provides your choice of either harrying fire or covering fire (see pages 246-247) against the enemy each round on your turn and it follows that enemy within range automatically unless you direct it to change targets. The wisp is made of pure light and energy and can't be damaged in combat though it can be dispelled as normal. In addition to the function described above the wisp sheds light in a 20-foot radius in a color of your choice (chosen when you cast the spell).

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8fQf6r5VV5jGIeAT_description
attribs.current: This spell short-circuits the mind of a humanoid creature with a CR of 3 or lower so that it is dazed (unable to take actions but taking no penalty to A.C.). Humanoids of CR 4 or higher are not affected. After a creature has been dazed by this spell it is immune to it for 1 minute.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8fQf6r5VV5jGIeAT_target
attribs.current: One humanoid creature of CR 3 or lower

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mf-8hZnix632xBg6CI5_description
attribs.current: You make a melee attack against a single target's EAC adding your key ability score modifier to the attack roll instead of your Strength modifier if it is higher. The target must succeed at a Fortitude save or be fatigued for the spell's duration. This spell has no effect on a creature that is already fatigued. Casting this spell doesn't provoke attacks of opportunity.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-8pNxAN-nGXSS4ZGc_description
attribs.current: When a Drift phantom scores a critical hit with its slam or static globe attack, the target must attempt a DC 15 Reflex saving throw. On a failure, all batteries in that creature’s possession lose 1d6 charges. If the creature isn’t carrying batteries, one randomly chosen object in its possession powered by electrical means other than batteries has its functions suppressed for 1d4 rounds instead.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-8pNxAN-nGXSS4ZGc_effect
attribs.current: On a failure, all batteries in that creature’s possession lose 1d6 charges. If the creature isn’t carrying batteries, one randomly chosen object in its possession powered by electrical means other than batteries has its functions suppressed for 1d4 rounds instead.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-9In8hTlq9QfZ4AOV_description
attribs.current: If the Drift phantom succeeds at a Reflex save against an effect that normally has a partial effect on a successful save, it instead suffers no effect. The Drift phantom loses the benefit when it is helpless or unable to move.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-AMOs-sFr8wkmSlyF_description
attribs.current: As a ranged attack, a Drift phantom can release an orb of static electricity with a range increment of 30 feet.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-AUxabsjogHBCLOkz_description
attribs.current: Flanking a Drift phantom doesn’t grant any bonuses, and abilities that function only against a creature that is flanked don’t function against a Drift phantom.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezaq6Ug9LUFH-RrsVi_description
attribs.current: Any creature that comes within 30 feet of a driftdead must succeed at a DC 11 Will save or be confused for 2 rounds. Once a creature has attempted this save, whether successful or not, it can’t be affected again by the same driftdead’s aura for 24 hours.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezaq6Ug9LUFH-RrsVj_description
attribs.current: Just as the Drift tears away chunks of planar material, a driftdead can pull apart the molecular bonds of matter, ripping apart nearby creatures. This is a ranged attack against EAC that has a range of 30 feet.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezaq6Ug9LUFH-RrsVk_description
attribs.current: Within the Drift, a driftdead has a physical body, but if removed from that plane, its physical body phases out of normal reality. On the Material Plane or otherwise outside the Drift, a driftdead gains the incorporeal special ability (Starfinder Core Rulebook 264). If returned to the Drift, a driftdead immediately loses the incorporeal special ability as its physical body is restored.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-B4O0bNjZzeZ9PJs6_description
attribs.current:
Undead are immune to the following effects, unless the effect specifies it works against undead creatures.
Bleed, death effects, disease, mind-affecting effects, paralysis, poison, sleep, and stunning.
Ability damage, ability drain, energy drain, exhaustion, fatigue, negative levels, and nonlethal damage.
Any effect that requires a Fortitude save (unless the effect works on objects or is harmless).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-B9iRvF5zquvVF5ql_description
attribs.current: A driftdead has no Constitution score or modifier. The creature is immediately destroyed when it reaches 0 Hit Points. An unliving creature doesn’t heal damage naturally, but magic effects can heal undead. Unliving creatures don’t breathe, eat, or sleep.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: estex suit I, pulsecaster pistol with 1 battery (20 charges), tactical baton

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The human gang members focus their attention on the toughest-looking character, and they close to melee so that they can attack with their tactical batons.
Morale Each True Warrior fights until reduced to 5 or fewer Hit Points, then flees. If two True Warriors flee, the third follows no matter how many Hit Points they have. Alternatively, if one True Warrior drops to 0 Hit Points, the other two run to the car, dragging their comrade's unconscious body with them.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: lashunta ringwear I, azimuth laser pistol with 1 battery (20 charges)

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The True Warrior tough cracks his knuckles and attacks the toughest-looking enemy with his meaty fists. If he has trouble landing a blow, he turns his attention to someone who looks weaker.
Morale With his standing in the gang on the line here, the True Warrior tough fights until he is knocked unconscious or killed.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-D3rPnYn2OUuEpmhw_description
attribs.current: When a junk golem begins its turn with half its HP or fewer, it must attempt a DC 11 Will save. On a failure, it goes berserk, using its actions to move and attack or make a full attack. If it can’t reach a creature, it attacks objects. The golem attempts a DC 11 Will saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the berserk state. If the golem’s creator communicates with it to calm it and succeeds at a DC 10 Charisma check, the golem gains a +2 circumstance bonus to this save.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-D3rPnYn2OUuEpmhw_effect
attribs.current: On a failure, it goes berserk, using its actions to move and attack or make a full attack.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DFg7aOXRz7oVsNtx_description
attribs.current:
Constructs are immune to the following effects, unless the effect specifies that it works against constructs.
Bleed, death effects, disease, mind-affecting effects, necromancy effects, paralysis, poison, sleep, and stunning.
Ability damage, ability drain, energy drain, exhaustion, fatigue, negative levels, and nonlethal damage.
Any effect that requires a Fortitude save (unless the effect works on objects or is harmless).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DMM-5zvTJmDeKvD9_description
attribs.current: When a junk golem is reduced to 0 Hit Points, it collapses in a landslide of debris. All Medium or smaller creatures adjacent to the junk golem take 1d8+9 bludgeoning damage (Reflex DC 13 half).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DMM-5zvTJmDeKvD9_effect
attribs.current: All Medium or smaller creatures adjacent to the junk golem take [[1d8+9]] bludgeoning damage

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DXrczJXp5WDlDHTY_description
attribs.current: Once a day, the golem can take a standard action to pick up 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment and add it to its body, restoring 1d10 HP.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DercXfVs4phDlzG-_description
attribs.current:
A junk golem is immune to any spell or spell-like ability that allows spell resistance, unless the spell specifically targets constructs. In addition, certain spells and effects function differently against the golem, as follows.
Magical effects that deal acid damage slow (as the slow spell) the junk golem for 3 rounds (no save).
If targeted by a spell with a Target entry of “at least 1 bulk of inert electronic equipment,” the golem becomes confused for 1d4 rounds. It attempts a Fortitude save (against the spell’s DC) at the end of each of its turns to end this condition.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-Dk3-Hd7uWVEXi7Ec_description
attribs.current: A junk golem has no Intelligence score or modifier and is immune to mind-affecting effects.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-DndN7p-jejyS65d9_description
attribs.current: The golem has no Constitution score or modifier and is destroyed when it reaches 0 HP. It doesn’t heal naturally, but can be repaired with the right tools. Unliving creatures don’t breathe, eat, or sleep.

attribs.name: weaknesses
attribs.current: vulnerable to critical hits, vulnerable to electricity

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: tactical arc emitter with 2 batteries (20 charges each)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezb3pvyDX8XMCTZZ7q_description
attribs.current: A security robot's weapons are integrated into its frame and can't be disarmed.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezb3pvyDX8XMCTZZ7r_description
attribs.current: Once every 1d4 rounds as a standard action, a patrol-class security robot can shoot an arc of electricity at up to four creatures within 40 feet (no two of which can be more than 30 feet apart). This arc deals 1d8 electricity damage to each target (Reflex DC 13 half).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mezb3pvyDX8XMCTZZ7s_description
attribs.current: A patrol-class security robot's nanites heal it, restoring a number of Hit Points per hour equal to its CR (4 Hit Points per hour for most security robots). Once per day as a full action, a patrol-class security robot can restore 3d8 Hit Points to itself or any touched construct with the technological subtype.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-E4B1AfwJsuZjFaZZ_description
attribs.current:
Constructs are immune to the following effects, unless the effect specifies that it works against constructs.
Bleed, death effects, disease, mind-affecting effects, necromancy effects, paralysis, poison, sleep, and stunning.
Ability damage, ability drain, energy drain, exhaustion, fatigue, negative levels, and nonlethal damage.
Any effect that requires a Fortitude save (unless the effect works on objects or is harmless).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-E9Zk7SPoPuuMOPZQ_description
attribs.current: A patrol-class security robot has no Constitution score or modifier. The creature is immediately destroyed when it reaches 0 Hit Points. An unliving creature doesn’t heal damage naturally, but a construct can be repaired with the right tools. Spells such as make whole can heal constructs. Unliving creatures don’t breathe, eat, or sleep.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-EC6yodB2n9Zsl1PU_description
attribs.current: A patrol-class security robot takes half again as much damage (+50%) from damage dealt by a critical hit.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-EEgqV4Uv8OvUfspU_description
attribs.current: A patrol-class security robot takes half again as much damage (+50%) from weapons and effects that deal electricity.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-FL2VuSVPa1RSYfBC_description
attribs.current: When a thastertoad successfully renews a grapple or a pin against an opponent, it automatically deals 1d8+2 bludgeoning damage to that creature.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-FnBnROfKWN8rR3JZ_description
attribs.current: If a thastertoad hits with its tongue attack, it deals the listed damage. If the thastertoad’s attack roll successfully hits the target’s KAC + 4, the thastertoad automatically grapples the target (this takes no action); if it hits the target’s KAC + 13, it instead pins the target. The thastertoad doesn’t need to have a limb free to perform this grapple as long as it can make a tongue attack. If the thastertoad moves farther than 10 feet from the grappled target or makes a tongue attack against a different target, the grappled condition ends immediately. The thastertoad can attempt to renew the condition on the target by attempting a grapple combat maneuver check, using its melee attack die roll modifier of +9.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-FsdfXzGet1hGqKEV_description
attribs.current: Plates of impure thasteron cover a thastertoad’s back, protecting it from some devastating injuries. There is a 20% chance that a critical hit against a thastertoad is treated as a normal attack, dealing normal damage instead and not applying any critical effect. Roll this percentage chance before critical hit damage is rolled.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: estex suit I, autotarget rifle with 25 longarm rounds, tactical dueling sword

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The lieutenant stays at the rear of the group, firing her autotarget rifle at enemies with ranged weapons or spells. If one of her allies is wounded, the lieutenant uses True Warrior spirit to grant temporary Hit Points to that ally.
Morale The lieutenant wants to impress Do’trulu by bringing him the heads of the player characters, but she doesn’t want to die. If reduced to 5 or fewer Hit Points, she flees.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-Mf-HIE5UHr2PoGXWELr_description
attribs.current: As a standard action, the True Warrior lieutenant can shout words of encouragement to an ally within 30 feet. That ally regains 5 Hit Points. Once an ally has benefited from this ability, that ally can’t gain the benefits of True Warrior spirit again that day. This is a mind-affecting, language-dependent, sense-dependent effect.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: flight suit stationwear, tactical semi-auto pistol with 9 small arm rounds, survival knife

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The ysoki gang member takes cover behind a crate and shoots at a character, especially one who displays magical abilities.
Morale Each True Warrior fights until reduced to 5 or fewer Hit Points, then flees. If two True Warriors flee, the third follows no matter how many Hit Points they have. Alternatively, if one True Warrior drops to 0 Hit Points, the other two run to the car, dragging their comrade's unconscious body with them if possible.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The khefaks move to attack the closest and most vulnerable characters, especially those that are Small or smaller. Despite their ability to break and consume objects, they don’t attack the heroes’ weapons or armor; instead, they try to kill the characters so that they can take their time feasting on equipment from the characters’ corpses.
Morale The khefaks fight to the death to protect their food.

attribs.name: tactics
attribs.current:
During Combat The thasteron khefak moves toward the nearest character and attacks with its hefty claws.
Morale The vermin is mindless and fights to the death, forcing the heroes to kill it to complete the job.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-MezwflroW1PdRvvt9Kk_description
attribs.current: You detect all technological items (even hybrid items) with charges or that replenish charges in the area including batteries power cells and generators (as well as such items that are on creatures you can see even if the creatures have hidden those items on themselves). You can't determine if there are technological items in areas you can't see nor can you detect technological traps in this way. The information this spell provides allows you to differentiate between charged items and items that replenish charges but it does not provide any further information nor does it tell you for example how many charges an item currently has or how many maximum charges it can hold. This spell can penetrate barriers but 3 feet of dirt or wood 1 foot of stone 1 inch of common metal a thin sheet of lead or any force field blocks it.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mezwi0RgEb2RF94ULVK_description
attribs.current: You touch a target with a device you're holding that uses electricity requiring a melee attack against the target's EAC. Alternatively you can instead touch an electrical device a target is wearing (or a target that is an electrical device such as a robot) with your hand gaining a +2 bonus to your attack roll. Either way if your attack hits the electrical device surges out of control dealing 4d6 electricity damage to your target. Casting this spell doesn't provoke attacks of opportunity.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-MezwjZTFxoQx5jLARgn_description
attribs.current: You detect all magic spells effects items and objects (including those on or affecting creatures you can see) as well as hybrid items in the area. You can't detect magical traps in this way as they are created with additional magic that wards them from this common spell. Each round you concentrate on the same area you can determine if one magic source you detect is from a spell magic item or other effect and the caster level (or item level) of the effect. You can't determine if there are magic sources in areas you can't see or if there was a magic source in an area at one time but that has since expired.

attribs.name: repeating_spell_-Mezwkk1qSb8tg5BL-5O_description
attribs.current: When you cast this spell choose acid cold electricity or fire; the spell gains that descriptor. You fire a ray at the target and you must make a ranged attack against its EAC. On a hit the ray deals 1d3 damage of the chosen energy type.

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezxI42mc11PrKcBojF_description
attribs.current:
Your spells break through spell resistance more easily than those of other spellcasters.
Benefit:
You gain a +2 bonus to caster level checks to overcome a creature’s spell resistance.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: freebooter armor I, survival knife, holy symbol of Zon-Kuthon

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezxTjJq5kYP3VmnjSo_description
attribs.current: Once per day as a move action, an ikeshti technomancer can squirt blood from one of their eyes at a foe within 30 feet, making a ranged attack (+6 for these ikeshti technomancers) against the target’s KAC. A successful hit grants the next ally who attacks that foe the benefit of harrying fire.

attribs.name: pilot_bonus
attribs.current: @{Space Goblin Junker|whisper_state}&{template:sf_generic} {{name=@{character_name}}} {{characterid=@{character_id}}} {{title=^{pilot}}} {{r1=[[1d20+@{|piloting_ranks}[RNK]+[[({0,@{|piloting_ranks}}>1) * @{|piloting_class_skill}]][CS]+@{|piloting_ability}[ABI]+2-2@{|piloting_misc}@{Space Goblin Junker|engines_status}@{Space Goblin Junker|power_core_status}@{Space Goblin Junker|computer_query}?{HELM PHASE INITIATIVE|NO, |YES,&{tracker}}]]}} {{r1name=}}

attribs.name: repeating_attack_-MezpmBVijsb3n5Qarno_description
attribs.current: A space goblin junker’s laser pistol is crafted from a mishmash of broken casings, leaking energy cells, and other random material. A junklaser is similar to an azimuth laser pistol, except it has a range of only 60 feet. If the wielder of a junklaser rolls a natural 1 when attacking with it, it must immediately attempt a DC 18 Engineering check. Success means that the junklaser gains the broken condition. Failure means that the gun explodes in 1d3–1 rounds, functioning as a fragmentation grenade I (explode [15 ft., 1d6 P, DC 10]); a result of 0 rounds means the junklaser explodes immediately—randomly determine the corner of the wielder’s square that’s the center of the burst. A thrown junklaser has the same range increment as a grenade.

attribs.name: gear
attribs.current: tattered flight suit (functions as broken flight suit stationwear), dogslicer (functions as survival knife), unstable junklaser (functions as azimuth laser pistol, but see below) with 1 battery (20 charges)

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezvEh8mZUWSRqNI8Fe_description
attribs.current: As a move action, a space goblin junker can remove the penalties associated with the broken condition from a single piece of equipment until the start of his next turn. The item then becomes unusable for 10 minutes (and retains the broken condition after that until it’s fixed).

attribs.name: repeating_ability_-MezvLzlpPix2HU-zPHk_description
attribs.current: A space goblin junker’s laser pistol is crafted from a mishmash of broken casings, leaking energy cells, and other random material. A junklaser is similar to an azimuth laser pistol, except it has a range of only 60 feet. If the wielder of a junklaser rolls a natural 1 when attacking with it, it must immediately attempt a DC 18 Engineering check. Success means that the junklaser gains the broken condition. Failure means that the gun explodes in 1d3–1 rounds, functioning as a fragmentation grenade I (explode [15 ft., 1d6 P, DC 10]); a result of 0 rounds means the junklaser explodes immediately—randomly determine the corner of the wielder’s square that’s the center of the burst. A thrown junklaser has the same range increment as a grenade.
